articles.headline: NBC News Picks Leader to Steer Turnaround
articles.snippet: Ms. Turness, a British news executive, will face the same challenges as her counterparts at ABC and CBS as television viewers spend more time online.
articles.abstract: Ms. Turness, a British news executive, will face the same challenges as her counterparts at ABC and CBS as television viewers spend more time online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deborah Turness was the first person interviewed for the prestigious job at the top of NBC News earlier this year. It was a telephone interview, because Ms. Turness was in London, where she oversaw ITV News. The person on the other end, Patricia Fili-Krushel, was so impressed that she flew Ms. Turness to New York for a follow-up.

articles.headline: U.S. and Europe Prepare to Settle Chinese Solar Panel Cases
articles.snippet: The plan that is starting to take shape in the world’s largest antidumping and antisubsidy trade cases would essentially carve up the solar panel market into a series of regional markets.
articles.abstract: The plan that is starting to take shape in the world’s largest antidumping and antisubsidy trade cases would essentially carve up the solar panel market into a series of regional markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Obama administration and the European Union have each decided to negotiate settlements with China in the world’s largest antidumping and antisubsidy trade cases involving China’s roughly $30 billion a year in solar panel shipments to the West, officials and trade advisers in Beijing, Brussels and Washington said.

articles.headline: Apple’s Web of Tax Shelters Saved It Billions, Panel Finds
articles.snippet: A Congressional inquiry’s findings were remarkable both for the tens of billions of dollars involved and for Apple’s audacity in saying some of its subsidiaries were stateless and beyond any tax authority’s reach.
articles.abstract: A Congressional inquiry’s findings were remarkable both for the tens of billions of dollars involved and for Apple’s audacity in saying some of its subsidiaries were stateless and beyond any tax authority’s reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Apple became the nation’s most profitable technology company, it avoided billions in taxes in the United States and around the world through a web of subsidiaries so complex it spanned continents and went beyond anything most experts had ever seen, Congressional investigators disclosed on Monday.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Charles Duhigg

articles.headline: Vast Oklahoma Tornado Kills Dozens
articles.snippet: Homes were flattened, cars flung through the air and at least two schools packed with children destroyed, sending rescuers to dig out those buried in rubble.
articles.abstract: Homes were flattened, cars flung through the air and at least two schools packed with children destroyed, sending rescuers to dig out those buried in rubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOORE, Okla. — A giant tornado, a mile wide or more, killed at least 91 people, 20 of them children, as it tore across parts of Oklahoma City and its suburbs Monday afternoon, flattening homes, flinging cars through the air and crushing at least two schools.
articles.byline: By Nick Oxford and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Japan’s New Optimism Has Name: Abenomics
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s economic shock therapy, which combines a flood of cheap cash, fiscal stimulus and deregulation, is getting early results.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s economic shock therapy, which combines a flood of cheap cash, fiscal stimulus and deregulation, is getting early results.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — After years of grinding malaise, Japan suddenly has some of its bling back.

articles.headline: SAC Capital Aims to Stem Withdrawal Requests
articles.snippet: SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for another round of withdrawal requests as fears grow that insider trading investigations could further damage Steven A. Cohen and his firm.
articles.abstract: SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for another round of withdrawal requests as fears grow that insider trading investigations could further damage Steven A. Cohen and his firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: The embattled hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is bracing itself for another round of withdrawal requests from investors after disclosing that it would no longer fully cooperate with the government’s scrutiny of its trading practices.

articles.headline: But Wait. Didn’t Yahoo Try a Deal Like This Before?
articles.snippet: Yahoo’s deal for Tumblr raises questions about its ability to make money by selling ads, among other thorny issues.
articles.abstract: Yahoo’s deal for Tumblr raises questions about its ability to make money by selling ads, among other thorny issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Yahoo announced its headline-grabbing acquisition, it boasted that the deal gave it access to an “unduplicated” audience of users and that its target was a “popular personal publishing” platform.

articles.headline: A Flashy Bet for Yahoo on a Shift in Social Media
articles.snippet: New services are moving beyond the Facebook approach, with tools to create new content instead of just sharing it.
articles.abstract: New services are moving beyond the Facebook approach, with tools to create new content instead of just sharing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s $1.1 billion proposed acquisition of Tumblr is a huge coup for the young founder of the even younger start-up and a splashy move by Marissa Mayer to shake up her company.

articles.headline: Before Tumblr, Founder Made Mom Proud. He Quit School.
articles.snippet: David Karp, 26, whose mother responded to his high school boredom with a suggestion that he try home-schooling, played a role in several start-ups before founding Tumblr.
articles.abstract: David Karp, 26, whose mother responded to his high school boredom with a suggestion that he try home-schooling, played a role in several start-ups before founding Tumblr.
articles.lead_paragraph: When David Karp was 14, he was clearly a bright teenager. Quiet, somewhat reclusive, bored with his classes at the Bronx High School of Science. He spent most of his free time in his bedroom, glued to his computer.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Viewers Start to Embrace Television on Demand
articles.snippet: Although it has been around for years, the technology is catching on among people who want to watch television on their own schedules.
articles.abstract: Although it has been around for years, the technology is catching on among people who want to watch television on their own schedules.
articles.lead_paragraph: While companies weigh bids for Hulu and industry heavyweights complain that TV Everywhere isn’t going much of anywhere, another way to watch time-shifted television is quietly gaining traction: video-on-demand, or VOD.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: For the Word on the Street, Courts Call Up an Online Witness
articles.snippet: Courts are looking to Urban Dictionary, a crowdsourced Web site, as one way to define words on which a case may turn.
articles.abstract: Courts are looking to Urban Dictionary, a crowdsourced Web site, as one way to define words on which a case may turn.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wheels of justice move slowly sometimes, but not, apparently, as slowly as Webster’s New World Dictionary.

articles.headline: Drama as Alarm Sirens Wailed
articles.snippet: Officials said it was still too early to say precisely how many people had been killed by the tornado in Oklahoma, but the toll appeared to be significantly less than initially feared.
articles.abstract: Officials said it was still too early to say precisely how many people had been killed by the tornado in Oklahoma, but the toll appeared to be significantly less than initially feared.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOORE, Okla. — At the end of the day on Monday, on the last week of the school year, students at Plaza Towers Elementary in this blue-collar suburb were zipping their backpacks. A fifth-grade class had just finished watching a movie about a boy who survives a crash-landing in the Canadian wilderness.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Strong Lobbying Helps Dimon Thwart a Shareholder Challenge
articles.snippet: The vote to split the roles of chairman and chief executive — both of which have been held by Jamie Dimon since 2006 — received only 32.2 percent of shares voted, down from a vote of roughly 40 percent in support of a similar proposal last year.
articles.abstract: The vote to split the roles of chairman and chief executive — both of which have been held by Jamie Dimon since 2006 — received only 32.2 percent of shares voted, down from a vote of roughly 40 percent in support of a similar proposal last year.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Even Before Apple Tax Breaks, Ireland’s Policy Had Its Critics
articles.snippet: Other countries have long been annoyed by Irish tax laws, but the benefit to the struggling country’s economy means the rules are unlikely to change.
articles.abstract: Other countries have long been annoyed by Irish tax laws, but the benefit to the struggling country’s economy means the rules are unlikely to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The secrets of how Apple avoided billions of dollars in taxes lie in a low-slung building of glass and brick in the hills of County Cork.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Eric Pfanner
